comment: Almost sweet smell, medium caramel color, medium oaky charred barrel taste (very nice), vanilla and caramel taste with full and sweet flavor with a hint of spice, incredibly smooth and semi sweet finish thanks to the port barrels! Excellent bourbon!
Enjoyable. But finish may be missing
Aroma of dried fruits, charred caramel, vanilla extract, light oak.  Caramel, cinnemon, sweet, very good
Vanilla with a hint of coconut, nice burn, with a smooth finish.
Honey, marshmallow, grape, smooth, but with a spicy finish.
Revisited this one again and gave it some more air to oxidize. For that reason, I enjoyed this one more the second go round. Upped my rating on this one a bit.
Not my thing. Can't put my finger on why but something in there I wasn't a fan of
Sweet with vanilla flavors. The port wine barrels come in at the end.
Fruity up front; like blackberries. The finish is long with hints of carrot cake.
I love the port wine finish.

Batch no. 75B - bottle 398

Nose : alcohol, sweet raisin (port) 
Palate: great mouth feel, a bit or red fruit, cinnamon 
Finish: oaky astringent 
long finish: fresh mint, candy, juice
Sweet and smooth with a mildly tart linger
Ethanol on the nose. Sweet smooth on the palate. spicy finish.

Angels Envy

Nose: the port really shines through with a pleasant mix of honey and vanilla 

Palate: super low heat with a lot of sweetness not as much vanilla as I got on the nose. Very fruity 

Finish 
Very nice long finish that stays pretty consistent 

Notes: Some similarities to Mid-winters night dram, but not a match.
Sweet start with a spicy finish. First time trying and buying. One to sip and enjoy neat.

Prefer neat

Batch 73(m?) Bottle 358

Nose: stone fruit
Taste: paper, cardboard, bland with water but finish becomes harsher
This is my goto when needing a sipper. Not as sweet as the rye, but just as smooth
Cherry soda, soft corn, spicy finish
A little sweet for my normal taste but a nice change-of-pace sipper for after-dinner conversations.

The corn sweetness melds well with the oak, lending a malt-like quality to the palate.  The malt-like character continues, as sweetness leads to wood spice.  The finish is less than memorable.  Be that as it may, I'll probably buy this once a year just to have a cool-looking bottle on the bourbon shelf.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Easy drinking. Reminds me of Basil Hayden.
The port finishes great in a whiskey sour
Caramely, oily, and apple cinnamony. Definitely good

Heard plenty about this and finally scored one. Info was on point. Delectable nose that is reminiscent of either ripened banana and/or sweetened nuts. Taste was dark fruit doused with some maple syrup. Very smooth!

Nose: Brown sugar, spice, and honey roasted peanuts.

Palate: raisins from the port barrels, with more brown sugar and spice, and some vanilla wafers. moderate sweetness. a little heat

finish: warm spice, moderate length

Absolutely nothing wrong with this bourbon, but its a little steep at $50. would gladly pay $40 but unless I start making more money it might be a rare buy.
Very smooth. Smells of apples, waffles maple syrup and chocolate. Great bourbon.
Nose is very friendly with a brown sugar, honey, and berry notes. The oak is there but very light. Taste is sweet up front, and a rounded off barrel taste to finish. My favorite whiskey to date
Absolute perfect blend of smooth, round, rich taste
Lots of flavor, not enough bite.
Sweet and floral with the port wine barrel taste noticeable in the aftertaste
Decent, but have had better and smoother.
Beautiful fruity nose. Hits the palate sweet before revealing the port wine barrel notes. Finish is a bit hot for the proof.
Caramel sweetness with hints of vanilla
Slow, starts off sweet (port) with a taste of heat when you swallow, caramel undertones
Southern molasses feel. A slow sipper
Smooth, like a newly shorn scrotum. Otherwise just sort of a low proof easy drink.
Sugary vanilla with a rich sugar raisin and heat on the back end
Heavy ethanol taste and feel almost overpowering. No flavors stand out initially. Slight fruit and wood in the end after a long finish.  Decent pour. Pass on the bottle.
Sweet on the palette. Medium finish - very smooth.
One of my favorite daily drinkers.
CBD gummy plus angels envy equal sweet dreams

Nose
Rich, vanilla, Cherry and dried fruit.  Oak and a sweet astringency.

Palate
Thinner than anticipated on the first sip, although following tastes seem to improve in this area.  I'm having difficulty picking out individual notes, but the overall feeling is pleasant.  I'm getting some raisin and quite prominent oak.  Not as much wine/port flavour as I would expect, which isn't a bad thing.  

Finish
Medium length.  Port flavour comes through in the finish.  Residual caramelized bitterness in the back of the throat. Tannins presumably from the port cask are present but not overpowering, and, to be honest, not as forefront as I would have expected. 

Overall a very enjoyable drink
A hard core bourbon that makes you want more
I know everyone loves this but not a fan
Nose is full of Vanilla and Fruit notes. Palate is sweet but somewhat dry. Port Barrel notes and mild heat on the finish. Not complex but not a bad pour.

I sense a whole lot of fruity flavors, with pretty minimal rich, vanilla, butterscotch type flavors. If you're into clean and sharp, fruity orientated whiskeys then this would be an excellent option. But if you're after rich, full bodied flavor and creamy mouth feels, this simply isn't the best option. I'm rating 3.5 simply because it isn't a bad bourbon, the flavor isn't 'bad', it's just not what I seek in a whiskey. A bit thin on the mouth feel as well. Looks pretty on my shelf, but not so sure how often I'll grab a pour of it.

The nose was very fruity. It also sort of smells pleasantly like cigarettea. Tastes SUPER floral, like drinking straigh rose petals. The tasting notes said raisin and vanilla, but to me, even the aftertaste is floral.

In direct taste test vs. Four Roses (4R) 

Both are really good and have very similar profiles.

Despite having a slightly lower proof,  the Angle’s (AE) had a more pronounced alcohol smell,  and seemed thinner on the tongue.

By comparison the 4R had a richer nose and taste;  and is my winner.

If had more AE, I’d set up a blind test to confirm my impressions.  Feel like I may be shortchanging AE in that regard. 

They are very close, but the 4R has a distinct cost and availability advantage; which provides me with some comfort in making the call with limited head-to-head tasting.
Buttery and smooth on the palate. Chocolate notes. Not much warmth or finish. Delicious for an easy sipper.

Copper in color early hint if mint in aroma. This leads to cherry and a touch of raspberry. Sweetness noted and a slight moment of smoke.  Flavor brings along the cherry ads some spice, notably clove and black pepper.  As I work through the glass some dark chocolate notes emerge. After adding a few drops of water, milk chocolate steps forward and the lingering flavor is of cocoa.  I'd say my favorite notes here.  It's good, but I prefer other bourbons more and definitely prefer their Rye to this.
Herbal, sage, pepper on the nose
Sweet port notes. Some spice. Very enjoyable
Smooth and lots of sweet deliciousness.
One of my favorites taste the Carmel and the sweet heat
Super fruity/ sweet aroma. Delightful little sip
The bottle is killer the whiskey... Not killer, it’s a little better than decent. It is smooth but no drastic unique notes come out on my pallet.. always thought this one was overrated.
I also get a hint of black pepper on the finish.  I like this a lot, sufficiently complex.

Color: a tad on the lighter side, more tan/gold than brown

Legs: decent pace of formation, good spacing around the glass

Nose: sweet notes from the port finish, light oak, buttercream and a tad of pepper/space

First sip: easy on the front of the pallet, spicy towards the back and warm on the way down. Not overly but a very light burn letting you know it's there

Taste: smooth, no real strong tastes, pretty even and dare I say bland?

Finish: ultra smooth, nothing intense to note, really good bourbon for those that don't like the spice of a rye.

Overall: I don't think the value is there for a $50 bottle, it's decent but I think there is more hype than hope with this one.  Good marketing and reputation.

Cool whip, cool whip whipping cream, that's what you'll get with this one. You'll also get a hint of that port wine finish when you swallow, and it is very friendly. When I drink bourbon I want a hit bourbon, this one hits you or just glazes you as a bourbon. Meaning it leaves you wanting more, you wish there was more, but the volume on this one is a little to quiet for me. I like the concept of port wine finishes, but this whiskey is like a muscle car, with a V6 engine instead of a V8 engine, you wish there was more there.

Smooth and fruity with plenty of sweetness. There's a little spice here in the forms of cinnamon and white pepper, but it is not overwhelming. Surprisingly, there is almost no wood or smoke here. Vanilla is noticeable but not overwhelming and there are some floral notes nearer to the finished that are mixed in with the minerals. Tartness is present, but it's minimal. The flavor is mild with some mineral backing, but the notes it has are good. Not super exciting, but enjoyable.
The nose is woody but wet and has a bit of rich red fruit, as well as some rye and spice. The palate is musty with some gross wood coming through strong. There are clear mineral notes, but there's also some nice dark cherry hanging out a bit along with some caramel that doesn't not taste like butterscotch but is not obnoxious either. There's a bit of spearmint that reminds me of mothballs and therefore grandpa's house. There's a fair bit of numbing clove too. It has an interesting profile going on, but the traditional wood, char, fruit, and caramel notes aren't all that great and the other flavors are odd. I appreciate the added fruitiness, but the result is kind of like a more subdued Old Forester Signature with some added spearmint. There's a dab of chocolate, but it's mild. Gross bread does make it into the finish. There are all sorts of syrupy sweet flavors that remind me of Arta Anejo, but that is is a questionable profile to begin with and certainly isn't what I want in a bourbon. There's complexity for sure, but the flavors are a mess. It isn't all bad, but this drink has a lot of faults. This is interesting and wants to be hedonistic, but it doesn't quite work. Still, I could sip it.
Very sippable bourbon. Low proof makes it that way in my opinion, plus it smells sweet and tastes sweet as well.  Not overly sweet, a very good sweet taste.

May be an unpopular opinion, but at this price range, I expected more. I've tried many bourbons that finish their last few months/years in [something else], and every one of them were stronger in proof and priced lower. 
It does have "delicious" flavors, but a bit of too much flavors, and I feel it loses it's identity as a bourbon. It is enjoyable, and I can understand people liking this drink, but for this price range, I would have at least expected a minimum of 100 proof and the feel for a bourbon. Sorry, it's just overrated to me. Won't be a repeat buy, but welcome, if offered.

Nose: Vanilla and brown sugar 
Neat: Vanilla, caramel, a little fruit
Rocks: Same with some maple
Smooth taste with a big bite good mixing bourbon

Batch No. 71K; Bottle No. 164

This is one I've conveniently skipped over due to price and scarcity in NC. But when I had the chance to pick up one in December, I figured might as well because I wasn't sure when I'd have another opportunity to buy a bottle.

The nose is a burst of stewed fruits. Dark, ripe fruits with added sugar. Reminiscent of a pie filling. It is similar to a light- or medium-bodied red wine that isn't dry on the palate. Similar to pinot noir, merlot, or grenache. Honestly for a 86.6 proof whiskey it smells really good.

I can see why a couple of my friends consider this their favorite "bourbon." It contains a rich, sweet fruit flavor that you do not get with most bourbons, especially at this proof point. I taste dark fruits, sweetness (combination of brown sugar and molasses), and a noticeable oak spice. The oak spice builds a little on the finish as well with hints of corn dust. For 86.6 proof it clearly punches above its abv weight in flavor. I've seen multiple reviews say this is corn-heavy, and I get almost none of that on the nose or palate.

I've enjoyed this bottle, but I still think it is overpriced for what you are getting. Before I finish the bottle I may try to buy the Isaac Bowman Bourbon Port Finish for comparison. It is $15 cheaper in NC, thus, if it is comparable in flavor then it's a no-brainer purchase when looking for port finishes.
Vanilla...spice...at the very end of the finish ...bubble gum!...wow
Had a sample of this. It just reminded me of a better tasting version of the 1920
This was the first Bourbon I ever had. Sweet carmel & vanilla flavors. Goes with anything sweet or savory. So far this is my favorite.
Can def smell the vanilla, might be able to catch the caramel on the palate

Faintly rosy golden amber 
Rise definitely noted on the nose, along with some fruit, vanilla and spice notes with a hint of eucalyptus.
Soft mouthfeel with a pop of heat at the back of the month, port comes through on the finish, mingling with cacao, oak and vanilla with hints of creamy peanut butter.
Longest notes are from the wood.  
It's good, but I'm not sure I'd drop the $50 on it again.  I'd be happier with a few others at that price point.
